Name: ma huang
ephedra
Biological: ephedra equisetina Bunge (mu zei ma huang)
ephedra intermedia Schrenk et Mey. (zhong ma huang)
Other: xin jiang xue lian hua (incorrectly called. xin jiang xue lian hua is a different herb.)

Maladies Treated: Cough and asthma of small children (external use)
Medical Function: L-ephedrine can increase the contraction of heart muscle thus increases the cardiac output.
L-ephedrine causes less arrhythmia than epinephrine but if there are physical diseases of the hearts or if the patients are using digitalis it can cause arrhythmia.
L-ephedrine can cause systolic and diastolic pressure to go up.
L-ephedrine can cause the smooth muscle to relax.
Ma huang water extract (boiled in water) has antibiotic property.
Promoting sweating and rid of cold due to excessive exposure to chill and wind where pores become tight and unable to sweat and pulse shows floating and large. Take when the herbal tea is warm.
Promoting urination if taken when the liquid of the herb tea is cool
Soothing wheezing asthma
Dosage: 2.5 g to 6 g. Large amount up to 15 g.
Samples of Formulae: ma huang tang (麻黃湯), ge gen tang (葛根湯)
Contraindications: Ma huang can excite the CNS. If the dosage is too large, toxic reactions include headache, restlessness, insomnia, palpitation, tightness in chest area, tears and nose dripping, discomfort, fever, sweating nonstop, upper belly discomfort, dry mouth, nausea, vomiting, ringing in the ears, body temperature and blood pressure rising, causing heart rate increase, heart attack, or stroke. Large dosage can suppress heart and cause the heart to slow down. Not to use in patients who are deficient, with instant sweating, cough with asthma due to qixu (qi deficient), pixu (spleen deficient) with edema, or patients with heart problems, hypertension, prostatitis, or glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency. Traditionally not used in diet formulae nor recreationally. Avoid prescribing without experience and diagnostic skill especially pulse reading. Prolonged use for weight loss has caused serious liver problems, severity ranging from mild enzyme elevations to acute liver injury or failure. Chronic use linked to chronic hepatitis-like syndrome; recovery is prompt upon cessation. Recurrence typical if restarted; rechallenge should be avoided. Do not use with furazolidone (Furoxone). May induce mania if used with phenelzine.
Research: L-ephedrine toxicity has been observed. Chronic use and misuse in the West for weight loss resulted in liver injury, ranging from enzyme elevation to acute liver failure. Chronic use can cause chronic hepatitis-like syndrome, prompt recovery upon stopping. Recurrence common upon restart. No cross-sensitivity between ephedra and other weight loss or herbal preparations.
Notes: FDA banned dietary supplements containing ephedra in USA effective April 12, 2004. Ban applies to supplements with ephedrine alkaloids including ephedra, ma huang, sida cordifolia, pinellia. Ban does not pertain to traditional Chinese herbal remedies, herbal teas regulated as conventional foods, or chemically synthesized ephedrine. If oral toxicity occurs induce vomiting and use laxative. Chloral hydrate or oxygen may be used if there are serious nervous reactions or spasms.

Saponins: cao ma huang: main saponin is l-ephedrine (40~90% of total saponins), pseudo-ephedrine, L-N-methylephedrine, d-N-methyl-pseudoephedrine, d-nor-pseudoephedrine, ephedine, benzyl-methylamine, 3,4-dimethyl-5phyloxazolidine, 2,3,4-trimethyl-5-phenyloxazolidine, 2,3,5,6-tetramethylpyrazine (soothing asthma).
mu zie ma huang: contains 1.15~1.75% saponin, L-ephedrine and d-pseudo-ephedrine.
zhong ma huang: contains 1.5% saponin, ephedroxane (anti-inflammatory). zhong ma huang has least saponin, mu zie ma huang has highest.
Vaporizing Ingredients: cao ma huang: 38 ingredients including 2,3,5,6-tetramethylpyrazine, 1-alpha-terpineol, beta-terpineol, terpineol-4, --menth-2-en-7-ol, 1,3,4-trimethyl-3-trimethyl-3-cyclohexene-1carboxaldehyde.

Maladies Treated: Effective against bacteria, viruses, and fungi causing diseases such as tuberculosis, inflammation of the stomach, edema of the legs, and skin problems.
Effective in treating neurological issues including insomnia, pain, and various neurological problems due to sedative and anesthetic effects.
Promotes healing of ulcerated wounds, shortening healing time by 1/3 to 2/3, especially effective in diabetic wounds, mouth ulcers, stomach ulcers, duodenal ulcers, bed sores, and burns.
Effective for prevention and treatment of hypertension, heart disease, and arteriosclerosis, enhancing cardiac contraction, dilating blood vessels, and lowering triglycerides.
Effective in treatment of liver conditions including hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and liver cirrhosis by lowering ALT, protecting liver cells and promoting liver cell regeneration, preventing cirrhosis.
Effective in treatment and assisting treatment of various tumors (due to PRCA factors and other anti-tumor substances).
Effective in scavenging free radicals associated with over 80 severe illnesses.
Inhibits Streptococcus mutans and other related streptococcal bacteria species that cause dental caries and related infections.
Medical Function: Controls blood glucose and modulates the metabolism of glucose and blood lipid, leading to decreased outputs of lipid peroxidation and scavenges free radicals (study conducted on diabetic rats).
Anti-microbial: inhibits growth of Staphylococcus aureus (golden staph).

Synergistic antibacterial effect when ethanolic extract of propolis (EEP) combined with antibiotics. Significant synergistic effect showed with streptomycin, cloxacillin and moderate effects except for ampicillin.
Promotes tissue healing, especially of ulcerated wounds including diabetic ulcers, mouth ulcers, stomach ulcers, duodenal ulcers, bed sores, and burns, reducing healing time significantly by 1/3~2/3.

Improving heart and brain circulation by enhancing cardiac muscle contraction, dilating blood vessels, reducing blood triglycerides, beneficial in prevention and treatment of conditions such as hypertension and arteriosclerosis.

Hepatoprotective: Lowers ALT (Alanine Transaminase), promotes liver cell regeneration, useful for treating hepatitis B, hepatitis C and cirrhosis. Such patients should avoid alcoholic propolis products and instead take higher doses of non-alcoholic propolis soft capsules or concentrated fluid.
No side effects have been noted so far, suitable for long-term usage.
Contraindications: Patients with liver conditions should not take alcoholic propolis products but should instead take higher levels of non-alcoholic propolis soft capsules or concentrates.
Research:
Ethanolic extract of propolis (EEP) was incubated with eight different common antibiotics in a culture medium containing a fixed amount of a standard strain of Staphylococcus aureus. The antibiotic compounds used were: penicillin G, doxycycline, streptomycin, cloxacillin, chloramphenicol, cefradine, ampicillin, and polymyxin B. They were used in varying concentrations, ranging between 0.000005–125.0 micrograms/ml or units, respectively. First, their minimal inhibitory concentrations were established in the absence of EEP. Then, EEP was added in concentrations up to 600 micrograms/ml. EEP showed a marked synergistic effect on the antibacterial activity of streptomycin and cloxacillin, and a moderate synergistic effect on the others—except ampicillin.
 Propolis inhibits the activity of several Streptococcus (鏈球菌) species that cause dental caries. Japanese researchers reported that laboratory rats fed with propolis developed significantly fewer caries compared to those on a regular diet. 
 Propolis can help control blood glucose levels and modulate glucose and lipid metabolism, leading to reduced lipid peroxidation and enhanced scavenging of free radicals in rats with diabetes mellitus. Propolis also exhibits inhibitory effects against the hepatitis B virus. In addition, propolis offers specific protection against Streptococcus mutans and several other streptococcal species closely related to the pathogen that causes strep throat. Streptococcus mutans is a key species responsible for dental caries. Flavonoids of propolis lower transaminase, enhancing liver cell regeneration and preventing liver cirrhosis.
Notes: Propolis is resinous sap collected by bees from trees, mixed with wax, used as hive sealant, preservative, disinfectant against fungi and bacteria, and preservation of dead animals or insects killed inside hives.
Chemical Ingredients: Vitamins B1, B2, B6, C, E

(1) Gum infection: yin hua detoxifying tea (銀花解毒散): jin yin hua (honeysuckle flower) 9 g, zhu ye (bamboo leaves) 9 g, xuan shen (scrophularia root) 9 g, lian qiao (forsythia fruit) 9 g, sheng gan cao (fresh licorice root) 4.5 g, boil with water to make tea. Name: luo shen hua
Common: English: rosselle, rozelle, sorrel, red sorrel, Jamaica sorrel, Indian sorrel, Guinea sorrel, sour-sour, Queensland jelly plant, jelly okra, lemon bush, Florida cranberry
French: oseille rouge, oseille de Guin嶪
Spanish: quimbomb chino, sereni, rosa de Jamaica, flor de Jamaica, Jamaica, agria, agrio de Guinea, quetmia 塶ida, vi鎙, vi雝ela
Portuguese: vinagreira, azeda de Guin, curur az嶮o, quiabeiro az嶮o
North Africa and the Near East: karkad or carcad

Medical Function: hypotensive
diuretic
cholagogue
lessen blood viscosity
stimulate intestinal peristalsis
disintoxication
antibiotic
expels oxalate[3]
anticancer
possess immuno-stimulatory activities[5]
possible anti-obesity agents, through their tendency to inhibit α-amylase[4][5]
Polyphenol extracts from this herb can attenuate nephropathy in experimental study in type 1 diabetes.[6]

In another study on patients with type II diabetes, mean of high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (HDLc) increased significantly (p=0.002), and total cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol, triglycerides, and Apolipoprotein B100 (Apo-B100) significantly decreased.[7]
Extracts exhibit activities against atherosclerosis, liver disease, cancer, diabetes and other metabolic syndromes.[8]

In a study using albino rats, leaf extracts caused general body weight gain and increased the weight of testis, epididymis, seminal vesicle. Cold water extract gave weakest effect; alcoholic extract gave strongest effect.[9]
Dosage: Make into decoction for orally consumption: 9～15 g, or brew in boiling water.
Contraindications: Due to the diuretic effect of the herb, those with weak kidney function should not use too often. It also contain large amount of organic acid, those with too much stomach acid should avoid using it.
Research: Polyphenol extracts can attenuate nephropathy in experimental study in type 1 diabetes.[6]
In another human study on type II diabetes, mean HDLc significantly increased (p=0.002). Significant decrease in total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides, Apo-B100 observed.[7]
Extracts exhibit activities against atherosclerosis, liver disease, cancer, diabetes and other metabolic syndromes.[8]

In rat experiment, leaf extracts caused body weight gain and increased the weight of reproductive organs (testis, epididymis, seminal vesicle); effect weakest with cold water extract, highest with alcoholic extract.[9]

Name: xian he cao
仙鶴草
Biological: Agrimonia eupatoria L. var. pilosa Mak

Maladies Treated: Excessive bleeding (not during menses) in the vagina
Medical Function: Stops bleeding
Cardiotonic effect
Inhibits Gram-Positive Bacteria
Rids of tape worms (Root sprout has anthelmintic effect)
For temporary relief of occasional stress that affects energy, digestion, nerves and emotions [1]
Dosage: 10 to 15 g. Large dosage can be 30 to 60 g. Concentrated extract: 0.5 to 2 g. External application: use appropriate amount.
Samples of Formulae: Cancer Treatment (Formula 1, source: Shanghai Chinese Medical Report): Ingredients: xian he cao 120 g (whole plant except the roots), da zao 100 pieces, rice 100 g. Wash xian he cao with water and boil with 500 c.c. of water. Simmer until 200 c.c. is left. Make porridge with rice and da zao. When the porridge is ready, add the strained liquid from xian he cao and bring to boil. Make into 2 servings. Take every day for 1 to 2 months.

Cancer Treatment (Formula 2, source: Middle Level Medical Journal, 1988, Aug issue): xian he cao 60 g. Add water 500 ml. Simmer to 300 ml. Take orally morning and night. 7 to 10 days is one therapy session.
Leukemia Formula: bu jin wan (補金丸)
Research: Inhibition of hepatitis B virus by an aqueous extract of this herb [2]
Chemical Ingredients: agrimonin A, B, C (仙鹤草甲、乙、丙素)
